channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
Students in Hong Kong will soon be given textbooks that say Hong Kong was never a British colony.
The books are part of China’s effort to instill a historical narrative in a city where a pro-democracy movement was crushed. https://t.co/m7Qolkigcg
Breaking News: A lawyer advising Donald Trump claimed to know about a “heated fight” among Supreme Court justices over whether to hear 2020 election arguments. https://t.co/4XCCSKmaDc

The leaders of France, Germany and Italy traveled to Ukraine on Thursday and will meet with President Volodymyr Zelensky for the first time since Russia’s invasion began. The visit comes as questions mount over European support for Ukraine. https://t.co/G9TerIdNTR https://t.co/QPyfy80jUF

“Lightyear,” an animated Disney film, is facing bans or restrictions in parts of Southeast Asia and the Middle East over a scene that shows a kiss between two women.
The United Arab Emirates has banned the film, and Malaysia has asked Disney to cut scenes.https://t.co/JiTzQKE2UF

Scientists are raising the alarm that in the coming years destruction related to climate change will reach nearly all 423 national parks in the U.S., which are particularly vulnerable to rising temperatures. https://t.co/10JvAYTzyw

A fisherman has confessed that he helped kill a British journalist and a Brazilian expert on Indigenous peoples and then went with the authorities to look for their bodies, according to Brazilian federal police. The men were missing since June 5. https://t.co/xljSUWz0al

Breaking News: Over the course of 10 months, nearly 400 car crashes in the U.S. involved advanced driver-assistance technologies, data from the country's top auto-safety regulator revealed. https://t.co/YVJr0zqNQe

President Biden signed an executive order on Wednesday aimed at protecting LGBTQ people from a cascade of legislation in conservative states that increasingly targets the rights of gays, lesbians, transgender youth and others. https://t.co/dtvh3S3nop

A Delaware man who flew a Confederate battle flag inside the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was convicted with his son on Wednesday by a federal judge of the top count in their indictment: obstructing the certification of the 2020 presidential vote. https://t.co/WdQnZ4lAoV

Breaking News: FDA advisers recommended that the Moderna and Pfizer coronavirus vaccines be authorized for children as young as 6 months old. Regulators could authorize both vaccines for use on an emergency basis later this week. https://t.co/iShu6oifTt

Internet Explorer was officially retired Wednesday. The web browser, introduced by Microsoft in 1995, was loved and loathed by a generation. "Even though I don’t use it anymore, I'm still going to miss the idea of it," said one user. https://t.co/tmJG7DQx1A
Confirmed: Dogs are still great. https://t.co/Bk9HnyLR9Q https://t.co/zpNmiPOtOD

A man who toured the Capitol with Rep. Barry Loudermilk the day before the Jan. 6 attack later marched on the building, the Jan. 6 committee said. The complex was closed to the public at the time and the group entered three different office buildings. https://t.co/4KdVV5oWgz

Over 10,000 visitors have evacuated Yellowstone after heavy rains and severe flooding slammed the national park, destroying roads and threatening homes. "I’ve heard this is a thousand-year event," said the superintendent of the park. https://t.co/6QG0Ujeufh https://t.co/PWHWGbwCbF
Breaking News: President Biden promised another $1 billion in military aid to Ukraine, including more long-range weapons. https://t.co/2dcAMWMLeH
Breaking News: The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.75%, the biggest single increase since 1994, signaling its urgency in the fight against inflation. https://t.co/LXMt53ittm

Bayou Dave has spent the last dozen years ridding a trash-choked Houston waterway of plastic and Styrofoam. He and his longtime deckhand haul the equivalent of about 250 full garbage bags out of the water each week. https://t.co/sneyK1pci8 https://t.co/wH6Lwg44Y9

President Biden chastised some of the largest oil companies for profiteering off surging energy prices. "At a time of war, refinery profit margins well above normal being passed directly onto American families are not acceptable," he wrote in a letter. https://t.co/QO5z0P4prZ

Women can no longer access a legal abortion in Oklahoma and South Dakota. In Missouri, they can no longer make an appointment.
Roe v. Wade remains the law of the land, but health care providers in some states are operating as if it were overturned. https://t.co/iIBNEmTamk

President Biden plans to appoint Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former mayor of Atlanta, to his White House staff as a senior adviser, a White House official said.
She will succeed Cedric Richmond as head of the White House Office of Public Engagement. https://t.co/lr02E5tFEb

Sharon Oster, an economist who shattered glass ceilings in academia as the first woman to become a tenured professor of the Yale School of Management and later as the first woman to be named its dean, died on Friday. She was 73. https://t.co/wy9MnytZ0z

Russian and Belarusian tennis players will be allowed to compete in the U.S. Open. "We chose not to hold the individual athletes accountable for the decisions of their respective governments," said the chief executive of the U.S. Tennis Association. https://t.co/wvTxMNrTHq

Three women in China were savagely beaten by a group of men after one of the women rejected an advance.
The attack set off a debate over women’s rights and the threat of sexual violence. It also highlighted how divisive feminism remains in the country. https://t.co/JPA2gw6Uai

Herschel Walker, the Republican nominee for Senate from Georgia, who has often spoken out against absentee fathers, publicly acknowledged having fathered a second son with whom he is not in contact. https://t.co/xWytvFJ3KJ

President Biden plans to appoint Keisha Lance Bottoms, the former mayor of Atlanta, to his White House staff as a senior adviser, a White House official said.
She will succeed Cedric Richmond as head of the White House Office of Public Engagement. https://t.co/X9O8zdTxo2

BTS is taking some time apart — a move that J-Hope called a "healthy, important part of our plan that will let BTS grow stronger."
The seven members, each an individual pop sensation, will take some time to explore their solo identities, they said. https://t.co/TttAEQTMbv https://t.co/eLAgCx79uW
Rep. Nancy Mace, a Republican who clashed with Donald Trump after the Jan. 6 attack, fended off a primary challenge in South Carolina. https://t.co/nXGZzD5Cfb
Chess is an ancient game that traces its roots back to India. Let reading this guide be your first step toward learning one of the most popular board games of all time. https://t.co/UfEsoHLv13

South Asian nations, home to hundreds of millions of humanity’s most vulnerable, are on the front lines of climate change.
As climatic extremes become the norm, it’s growing more difficult to address poverty, food security and health challenges. https://t.co/iqlhtPVZX4 https://t.co/XvAjPGbRRC
Why do cats love catnip? They brim with euphoria, getting high off the stuff. Researchers believe it has an evolutionary advantage. https://t.co/2sUvYUu8UA https://t.co/nBSApgETyl

After nearly a decade together, the seven members of BTS need some time apart.
The K-pop juggernaut will take a break to allow its members to explore solo careers, the singers announced by video. https://t.co/h3CViKnxVe https://t.co/qWm3IPW93O

After nearly a decade together, the seven members of BTS need some time apart.
The K-pop juggernaut will take a break to allow its members to explore solo careers, the singers announced by video. https://t.co/ve5IKhs3gg

Flooding caused by record rainfall washed away roads and destroyed houses in Yellowstone National Park. Visitors were evacuated and entrances were closed. It was unclear when the park would reopen. https://t.co/PVuIE94TuZ https://t.co/H0YggLQm2C

Happy, an elephant that has been at the Bronx Zoo for more than 40 years, is not a person, New York’s highest court ruled. The decision was a legal blow for animal rights activists who argued she was being illegally detained. https://t.co/9UcbVnbCI6 https://t.co/kxS5hFbIUc

Lizzo, a Grammy-winning singer, changed a lyric on her song “Grrrls” within days of its release after it was criticized for containing a derogatory term for people with disabilities. “This is the result of me listening and taking action,” she said. https://t.co/bvGSvkT0va

The FDA on Monday approved a drug that restores hair growth in many alopecia patients. The approval is important for insurance coverage of these expensive drugs, which have a list price of nearly $2,500 a month. https://t.co/4RQPr0DrnH https://t.co/pR8hmVtm0g

Houston hasn’t ended homelessness, but it shows progress is possible.
Through cooperation, trust and grinding effort, the city has made remarkable progress moving people from the streets into homes of their own. https://t.co/sk2GLxNOpl

SpaceX can launch a giant new rocket to orbit from South Texas, the FAA said on Monday. Starship is central to NASA’s plans to return to the moon as well as the vision of Elon Musk, the company’s founder, to colonize Mars. https://t.co/K80jGaaQsF
The FDA on Monday approved a drug that restores hair growth in many alopecia patients by blocking the immune system from attacking hair follicles. https://t.co/hOCzDr6Y34

Derek Kammerzell, an assistant police chief in Kent, Washington, was placed on paid administrative leave after he taped a Nazi insignia to his office door in 2020.
He will now be paid more than $1.5 million to resign. https://t.co/IC8NHrg6pd

In Opinion
“The longer Germany, the most powerful and influential country on the continent, hesitates, the more devastation Mr. Putin can unleash,” says Jagoda Marinić, who writes about German politics. “There should be no more time for delay.” https://t.co/Y1NQif5vA1

Russia earned what is very likely a record 93 billion euros in revenue from exports of oil, gas and coal in the first 100 days of the country’s invasion of Ukraine, a new analysis shows. The revenue exceeds what Russia is spending on the war. https://t.co/rNDfnIhFee

President Volodymyr Zelensky gave a speech wearing a T-shirt designed by a Singaporean teenager.
“It’s a young Ukrainian girl defiantly painting a new future because self-belief is the best middle finger to oppression,” the 16-year-old designer said. https://t.co/6h4Ej8gj1f

Brittney Griner’s WNBA team, the Phoenix Mercury, met with U.S. State Department officials to discuss the status of her detainment. She has been held in Russia since Feb. 17, after customs officials accused her of carrying hashish oil in her luggage. https://t.co/IFkBcLsGBE
Three doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine appear to be effective in preventing Covid illness in children under 5, the FDA said on Sunday. https://t.co/hQxyHmJB4M

Eugene Goodman, the Capitol Police officer who led a pro-Trump mob away from the entrance to the Senate chamber during the Jan. 6 attack, testified for the first time on Monday about his experience holding off the rioters. https://t.co/HvjSzN3wJ8 https://t.co/7WCT9GfMJs
Several of Donald Trump’s closest advisers urged him not to declare victory on election night in 2020. Instead, he listened to Rudy Giuliani. https://t.co/Aw4H42TtlB

Former Attorney General Bill Barr suggested Donald Trump had grown "detached from reality" on his election fraud claims, as multiple aides testified to the House Jan. 6 committee they told him he'd lost. https://t.co/ePvQiEoaOH https://t.co/4aSQt2itzs

Meet Daniel Naroditsky, the New York Times's new chess columnist. He's an author, tutor and chess grandmaster — the highest title given to competitors by the International Chess Federation. He will be publishing his first Times chess puzzle on Monday. https://t.co/ZbjT7mlSFa
The FDA on Monday approved a drug that restores hair growth in many alopecia patients by blocking the immune system from attacking hair follicles. https://t.co/zxfmWCsdlh
